title: Easy Ways to Enable File Sharing Over a Network (Locally)

steps.title: Right-click the folder you want to share in File Explorer.
steps.content: Right-click the folder you want to share in File Explorer. Press Win + E to open File Explorer, then navigate to the folder that you want to share. Right-click it to open the context menu. If you get an error message like "Network discovery is turned off," you'll need to turn it on. To turn it on, you can do 1 of 2 things: Click the error message in File Explorer and select Turn on discovery and file sharing . Go to "Network and Internet" in Control Panel, then go to Change advanced settings and make sure "Turn on network discovery" is enabled.

steps.title: Click Show more options.
steps.content: Click Show more options . More likely than not, you'll need to click the Show more button to find the access button. Skip this step if you're using Windows 10.

steps.title: Click Give access to.
steps.content: Click Give access to . Another menu pops up to the side.

steps.title: Click Specific people.
steps.content: Click Specific people . You'll see a list of everyone on your network that you can share files with, but you can type their name in the search bar if the list of network users is long. You can also choose "Everyone" to share the folder or file with anyone on the network. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Share.
steps.content: Click Share . You'll need administrative permissions to share most folders and files with others. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Press Ctrl as you click to select multiple files or folders that you want to share. You can share multiple things at the same time locally. You can also use Nearby Share if you don't want to share the file locally over your network. For larger files and folders, you might need to use a USB drive to share data.

steps.title: Open System Settings.
steps.content: Open System Settings. You can share files from your macOS system with other users on your local network (even if they are using Windows). The first thing you'll need to do is enable File Sharing.

steps.title: Click General.
steps.content: Click General . It's next to a gear icon.

steps.title: Click Sharing.
steps.content: Click Sharing . You may need to scroll down to find this. It's in the last grouping of menu options.

steps.title: Click the switch next to "File Sharing" to enable it.
steps.content: Click the switch next to "File Sharing" to enable it. You'll see this under the "Content & Media" header.

steps.title: Click next to "File Sharing."
steps.content: Click next to "File Sharing." Another menu will open.

steps.title: Click + under "Shared Folders."
steps.content: Click + under "Shared Folders." This allows you to navigate through Finder to a folder or file that you want to share on your network. If you want to share your entire computer with everyone on the network, skip this step and instead click the switch next to "Allow full disk access for all users" to enable it. The Public folder of each user is automatically shared. You can stop sharing a folder by clicking it, then clicking - under "Shared Folders."

steps.title: Click + under "Users."
steps.content: Click + under "Users." By default, profiles in your Users & Groups settings can access shared files, but you can also specify with whom to share your data. These are your options: Add users or groups from all users of your Mac: Only use this if the person you want to add to the file is also a user on your computer. Add users or groups from everyone on your network: You can add more than one person from your network to view or edit your file. Add someone from your contacts and create a sharing-only account for them: Use this method if the person you want to share the folder with does not have a device on your network or does not already have a profile on your Mac. This creates an account for them so they can see your folders.

steps.title: Adjust the settings for each folder.
steps.content: Adjust the settings for each folder. You don't have to give everyone Read & Write access to your folders; you can adjust the settings as you like. Click their username in the shared list, then choose: Read & Write Read only Write only No Access

steps.title: Click Done.
steps.content: Click Done . The window will close. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Apple menu and select “System Preferences.”
steps.content: Open the Apple menu and select “System Preferences.” You can share files from your macOS system with other users on your local network (even if they are using Windows). The first thing you'll need to do is enable File Sharing. You'll need to have a local network already set up to use this method.

steps.title: Click to the “Sharing” pane.
steps.content: Click to the “Sharing” pane. This is where you can change sharing options and security permissions for users on your system. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Place a check in the box next to “File Sharing.”
steps.content: Place a check in the box next to “File Sharing.” When this box is checked, you'll see “File Sharing: On” on the main pane. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Return to System Preferences and select “Users & Groups.”
steps.content: Return to System Preferences and select “Users & Groups.” If you want to be able to share a folder with Windows users on your network, you'll need to create a special account for them. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Click the padlock to log in as an Administrator.
steps.content: Click the padlock to log in as an Administrator. This will give you permission to add a new account to the system.

steps.title: Create the new user account.
steps.content: Create the new user account. Here's how to configure the account so it's used only for sharing: Click the “+” to add a new account. Select “Sharing Only” from the “New Account” menu. Select “Use separate password” rather than the cloud option. Enter a username and password for the account. Click “Create User.” When Windows users access the shared folder, they'll need to use this username and password to log in.

steps.title: Return to System Preferences and select “Sharing.”
steps.content: Return to System Preferences and select “Sharing.” Now you'll decide which folders to share.

steps.title: Click on the (+) icon below "Shared Folders."
steps.content: Click on the (+) icon below "Shared Folders." A navigation window will appear. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Select a folder you want to share and click “Add.”
steps.content: Select a folder you want to share and click “Add.” The folder name will now appear under “Shared Folders.”

steps.title: Select the shared folder and click the “Options…” button.
steps.content: Select the shared folder and click the “Options…” button. Here you'll see options for file sharing protocols.

steps.title: Check “Share files using AFP.”
steps.content: Check “Share files using AFP.” This tells your Mac to share files with AFP (Apple Filing Protocol).

steps.title: Check “Share files using SMB” if you want to share with Windows computers.
steps.content: Check “Share files using SMB” if you want to share with Windows computers. If you will never need to share with a Windows computer on your network, you can skip this step.

steps.title: Click “Done.”
steps.content: Click “Done.” Now you'll return to the Sharing screen.

steps.title: Click the “+” beneath the “Users” box.
steps.content: Click the “+” beneath the “Users” box. A list of user accounts and groups will appear.

steps.title: Set permissions for your special Windows user account.
steps.content: Set permissions for your special Windows user account. Select the user account you just created, and then select either “Read,” “Read and Write,” or “Write” from the list on the right. Choose “Read & Write” if you want the Windows users to be able to read, edit, and delete items in this folder. [8] X Research source Choose “Write” if you want users to be able to use this folder as a “drop box” but not be able to edit or delete files. Alternatively, you can leave this on “Read” so nobody else can modify the folder.

steps.title: Set the permissions for everyone else on the network.
steps.content: Set the permissions for everyone else on the network. By default, all users on the network (the “Everyone” group) have Read access. This means they can view files in the shared folder but not make changes. To change this: Click to select “Everyone” in the Users list. Choose “Read & Write” from the right panel if you want users on the network to view, edit, and delete files in this folder. Select “Write” to use this folder as a “drop box,” so that people can copy files but not view or modify anything. Alternatively, you can leave this on “Read” so nobody else can modify the folder.

steps.title: Access the shared folder from another Mac on the network.
steps.content: Access the shared folder from another Mac on the network. Now that the folder is shared, any user on your network should be able to locate it in Finder beneath “Shared.” [9] X Research source If the folder does not appear under “Shared,” browse the network by double-clicking “All…” and the folders should appear.

steps.title: Locate the sharing address for Windows users.
steps.content: Locate the sharing address for Windows users. If you enabled SMB for Windows users, here's how to locate the address to which they'll connect: [10] X Research source Open System Preferences Open the Sharing pane. Make note of the IP address that starts with “smb” (e.g. smb://172.1.1.1). Windows users will connect to this address and log in with the account you created earlier. They'll be able to view any files shared with that user upon a successful login.
